author: Grimms
text: The wife of a rich man fell sick; and when she felt that her end drew nigh, she called her only daughter to her bed-side, and said, "Always be a good girl, and I will look down from heaven and watch over you."

author: Grimms
text: Soon afterwards she shut her eyes and died, and was buried in the garden; and the little girl went every day to her grave and wept, and was always good and kind to all about her.

author: Grimms
text: And the snow fell and spread a beautiful white covering over the grave; but by the time the spring came, and the sun had melted it away again, her father had married another wife.

author: Grimms
text: This new wife had two daughters of her own, that she brought home with her; they were fair in face but foul at heart, and it was now a sorry time for the poor little girl.

author: Grimms
text: "What does the good-for-nothing want in the parlour?" said they; "they who would eat bread should first earn it; away with the kitchen-maid!"

author: Grimms
text: Then they took away her fine clothes, and gave her an old grey frock to put on, and laughed at her, and turned her into the kitchen.

author: Grimms
text: There she was forced to do hard work; to rise early before daylight, to bring the water, to make the fire, to cook and to wash.

author: Grimms
text: Besides that, the sisters plagued her in all sorts of ways, and laughed at her.

author: Grimms
text: In the evening when she was tired, she had no bed to lie down on, but was made to lie by the hearth among the ashes; and as this, of course, made her always dusty and dirty, they called her Ashputtel.

author: Grimms
text: It happened once that the father was going to the fair, and asked his wife"s daughters what he should bring them.

author: Grimms
text: "Fine clothes," said the first; "Pearls and diamonds," cried the second.

author: Grimms
text: "Now, child," said he to his own daughter, "what will you have?"

author: Grimms
text: "The first twig, dear father, that brushes against your hat when you turn your face to come homewards," said she.

author: Grimms
text: Then he bought for the first two the fine clothes and pearls and diamonds they had asked for: and on his way home, as he rode through a green copse, a hazel twig brushed against him, and almost pushed off his hat: so he broke it off and brought it away; and when he got home he gave it to his daughter.

author: Grimms
text: Then she took it, and went to her mother"s grave and planted it there; and cried so much that it was watered with her tears; and there it grew and became a fine tree.

author: Grimms
text: Three times every day she went to it and cried; and soon a little bird came and built its nest upon the tree, and talked with her, and watched over her, and brought her whatever she wished for.

author: Grimms
text: Now it happened that the king of that land held a feast, which was to last three days; and out of those who came to it his son was to choose a bride for himself.

author: Grimms
text: Ashputtel"s two sisters were asked to come; so they called her up, and said, "Now, comb our hair, brush our shoes, and tie our sashes for us, for we are going to dance at the king"s feast."

author: Grimms
text: Then she did as she was told; but when all was done she could not help crying, for she thought to herself, she should so have liked to have gone with them to the ball; and at last she begged her mother very hard to let her go.

author: Grimms
text: "You, Ashputtel!" said she; "you who have nothing to wear, no clothes at all, and who cannot even dance--you want to go to the ball?

author: Grimms
text: And when she kept on begging, she said at last, to get rid of her, "I will throw this dishful of peas into the ash-heap, and if in two hours" time you have picked them all out, you shall go to the feast too."

author: Grimms
text: Then she threw the peas down among the ashes, but the little maiden ran out at the back door into the garden, and cried out:

author: Grimms
text: "Hither, hither, through the sky, Turtle-doves and linnets, fly!

author: Grimms
text: Blackbird, thrush, and chaffinch gay, Hither, hither, haste away!

author: Grimms
text: One and all come help me, quick!

author: Grimms
text: Haste ye, haste ye!--pick, pick, pick!"

author: Grimms
text: Then first came two white doves, flying in at the kitchen window; next came two turtle-doves; and after them came all the little birds under heaven, chirping and fluttering in: and they flew down into the ashes.

author: Grimms
text: And the little doves stooped their heads down and set to work, pick, pick, pick; and then the others began to pick, pick, pick: and among them all they soon picked out all the good grain, and put it into a dish but left the ashes.

author: Grimms
text: Long before the end of the hour the work was quite done, and all flew out again at the windows.

author: Grimms
text: Then Ashputtel brought the dish to her mother, overjoyed at the thought that now she should go to the ball.

author: Grimms
text: But the mother said, "No, no! you slut, you have no clothes, and cannot dance; you shall not go."

author: Grimms
text: And when Ashputtel begged very hard to go, she said, "If you can in one hour"s time pick two of those dishes of peas out of the ashes, you shall go too."

author: Grimms
text: And thus she thought she should at least get rid of her.

author: Grimms
text: So she shook two dishes of peas into the ashes.

author: Grimms
text: But the little maiden went out into the garden at the back of the house, and cried out as before:

author: Grimms
text: "Hither, hither, through the sky, Turtle-doves and linnets, fly!

author: Grimms
text: Blackbird, thrush, and chaffinch gay, Hither, hither, haste away!

author: Grimms
text: One and all come help me, quick!

author: Grimms
text: Haste ye, haste ye!--pick, pick, pick!"

author: Grimms
text: Then first came two white doves in at the kitchen window; next came two turtle-doves; and after them came all the little birds under heaven, chirping and hopping about.

author: Grimms
text: And they flew down into the ashes; and the little doves put their heads down and set to work, pick, pick, pick; and then the others began pick, pick, pick; and they put all the good grain into the dishes, and left all the ashes.

author: Grimms
text: Before half an hour"s time all was done, and out they flew again.

author: Grimms
text: And then Ashputtel took the dishes to her mother, rejoicing to think that she should now go to the ball.

author: Grimms
text: But her mother said, "It is all of no use, you cannot go; you have no clothes, and cannot dance, and you would only put us to shame": and off she went with her two daughters to the ball.

author: Grimms
text: Now when all were gone, and nobody left at home, Ashputtel went sorrowfully and sat down under the hazel-tree, and cried out:

author: Grimms
text: "Shake, shake, hazel-tree, Gold and silver over me!"

author: Grimms
text: Then her friend the bird flew out of the tree, and brought a gold and silver dress for her, and slippers of spangled silk; and she put them on, and followed her sisters to the feast.

author: Grimms
text: But they did not know her, and thought it must be some strange princess, she looked so fine and beautiful in her rich clothes; and they never once thought of Ashputtel, taking it for granted that she was safe at home in the dirt.

author: Grimms
text: The king"s son soon came up to her, and took her by the hand and danced with her, and no one else: and he never left her hand; but when anyone else came to ask her to dance, he said, "This lady is dancing with me."

author: Grimms
text: Thus they danced till a late hour of the night; and then she wanted to go home: and the king"s son said, "I shall go and take care of you to your home"; for he wanted to see where the beautiful maiden lived.

author: Grimms
text: But she slipped away from him, unawares, and ran off towards home; and as the prince followed her, she jumped up into the pigeon-house and shut the door.

author: Grimms
text: Then he waited till her father came home, and told him that the unknown maiden, who had been at the feast, had hid herself in the pigeon-house.

author: Grimms
text: But when they had broken open the door they found no one within; and as they came back into the house, Ashputtel was lying, as she always did, in her dirty frock by the ashes, and her dim little lamp was burning in the chimney.

author: Grimms
text: For she had run as quickly as she could through the pigeon-house and on to the hazel-tree, and had there taken off her beautiful clothes, and put them beneath the tree, that the bird might carry them away, and had lain down again amid the ashes in her little grey frock.

author: Grimms
text: The next day when the feast was again held, and her father, mother, and sisters were gone, Ashputtel went to the hazel-tree, and said:

author: Grimms
text: "Shake, shake, hazel-tree, Gold and silver over me!"

author: Grimms
text: And the bird came and brought a still finer dress than the one she had worn the day before.

author: Grimms
text: And when she came in it to the ball, everyone wondered at her beauty: but the king"s son, who was waiting for her, took her by the hand, and danced with her; and when anyone asked her to dance, he said as before, "This lady is dancing with me."

author: Grimms
text: When night came she wanted to go home; and the king"s son followed here as before, that he might see into what house she went: but she sprang away from him all at once into the garden behind her father"s house.

author: Grimms
text: In this garden stood a fine large pear-tree full of ripe fruit; and Ashputtel, not knowing where to hide herself, jumped up into it without being seen.

author: Grimms
text: Then the king"s son lost sight of her, and could not find out where she was gone, but waited till her father came home, and said to him, "The unknown lady who danced with me has slipped away, and I think she must have sprung into the pear-tree."

author: Grimms
text: The father thought to himself, "Can it be Ashputtel?"

author: Grimms
text: So he had an axe brought; and they cut down the tree, but found no one upon it.

author: Grimms
text: And when they came back into the kitchen, there lay Ashputtel among the ashes; for she had slipped down on the other side of the tree, and carried her beautiful clothes back to the bird at the hazel-tree, and then put on her little grey frock.

author: Grimms
text: The third day, when her father and mother and sisters were gone, she went again into the garden, and said:

author: Grimms
text: "Shake, shake, hazel-tree, Gold and silver over me!"

author: Grimms
text: Then her kind friend the bird brought a dress still finer than the former one, and slippers which were all of gold: so that when she came to the feast no one knew what to say, for wonder at her beauty: and the king"s son danced with nobody but her; and when anyone else asked her to dance, he said, "This lady is /my/ partner, sir."

author: Grimms
text: When night came she wanted to go home; and the king"s son would go with her, and said to himself, "I will not lose her this time"; but, however, she again slipped away from him, though in such a hurry that she dropped her left golden slipper upon the stairs.

author: Grimms
text: The prince took the shoe, and went the next day to the king his father, and said, "I will take for my wife the lady that this golden slipper fits."

author: Grimms
text: Then both the sisters were overjoyed to hear it; for they had beautiful feet, and had no doubt that they could wear the golden slipper.

author: Grimms
text: The eldest went first into the room where the slipper was, and wanted to try it on, and the mother stood by.

author: Grimms
text: But her great toe could not go into it, and the shoe was altogether much too small for her.

author: Grimms
text: Then the mother gave her a knife, and said, "Never mind, cut it off; when you are queen you will not care about toes; you will not want to walk."

author: Grimms
text: So the silly girl cut off her great toe, and thus squeezed on the shoe, and went to the king"s son.

author: Grimms
text: Then he took her for his bride, and set her beside him on his horse, and rode away with her homewards.

author: Grimms
text: But on their way home they had to pass by the hazel-tree that Ashputtel had planted; and on the branch sat a little dove singing:

author: Grimms
text: "Back again! back again! look to the shoe!

author: Grimms
text: The shoe is too small, and not made for you!

author: Grimms
text: Prince! prince! look again for thy bride, For she"s not the true one that sits by thy side."

author: Grimms
text: Then the prince got down and looked at her foot; and he saw, by the blood that streamed from it, what a trick she had played him.

author: Grimms
text: So he turned his horse round, and brought the false bride back to her home, and said, "This is not the right bride; let the other sister try and put on the slipper."

author: Grimms
text: Then she went into the room and got her foot into the shoe, all but the heel, which was too large.

author: Grimms
text: But her mother squeezed it in till the blood came, and took her to the king"s son: and he set her as his bride by his side on his horse, and rode away with her.

author: Grimms
text: But when they came to the hazel-tree the little dove sat there still, and sang:

author: Grimms
text: "Back again! back again! look to the shoe!

author: Grimms
text: The shoe is too small, and not made for you!

author: Grimms
text: Prince! prince! look again for thy bride, For she"s not the true one that sits by thy side."

author: Grimms
text: Then he looked down, and saw that the blood streamed so much from the shoe, that her white stockings were quite red.

author: Grimms
text: So he turned his horse and brought her also back again.

author: Grimms
text: "This is not the true bride," said he to the father; "have you no other daughters?"

author: Grimms
text: "No," said he; "there is only a little dirty Ashputtel here, the child of my first wife; I am sure she cannot be the bride."

author: Grimms
text: The prince told him to send her.

author: Grimms
text: But the mother said, "No, no, she is much too dirty; she will not dare to show herself."

author: Grimms
text: However, the prince would have her come; and she first washed her face and hands, and then went in and curtsied to him, and he reached her the golden slipper.

author: Grimms
text: Then she took her clumsy shoe off her left foot, and put on the golden slipper; and it fitted her as if it had been made for her.

author: Grimms
text: And when he drew near and looked at her face he knew her, and said, "This is the right bride."

author: Grimms
text: But the mother and both the sisters were frightened, and turned pale with anger as he took Ashputtel on his horse, and rode away with her.

author: Grimms
text: And when they came to the hazel-tree, the white dove sang:

author: Grimms
text: "Home! home! look at the shoe!

author: Grimms
text: Princess! the shoe was made for you!

author: Grimms
text: Prince! prince! take home thy bride, For she is the true one that sits by thy side!"

author: Grimms
text: And when the dove had done its song, it came flying, and perched upon her right shoulder, and so went home with her.
